comment.author: 30484128@N03
comment._content:
They were having a bit of fun.
Hope their lives went well.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: I attended the Ursuline briefly as an infant and grew up within a stones throw of it. This is it on google street view, g.co/maps/2fc42

comment.author: 32162360@N00
39191857@N05
comment._content: I think they were learning useful womanly skills like washing, ironing, cooking and cleaning;-). ( in jest Carol, some of my best friends are women!). Such dreadful hairdo's?  I expect that it was for hygiene purposes.

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Well I grew up in the 1970s and thus learned no useful skills whatsoever.
I would have loved to have learned at least some "womanly skills".
As for the hairdo, I think it looks great.
It was the fashion back then, you can see it in more photos although often women would wear hats that sort of cover the hugeness.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/99684904@N00] You should be ashamed, in the 1970's I could wash, sew, iron, cook and clean. 

I got married in 1970 and had to learn very quick!

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] I was -2 when you got married!
I was 8 when the 1970s ended, bit young to have learned to wash, sew, iron, cook and clean.
At least, according to my hippy parents.
I agree, I wish I had learned any of those things as a child, but I never did, ever.
Not part of my education.
Had to learn it myself from old magazines and books when I adapted a 1930s lifestyle.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Call me a silly old fool, but most of these ladies look well past school age.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] You're a silly old fool! (Sorry, couldn't resist!)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/] See?  Young people today, no respect for their elders.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] So you were an "Ursuline Boy" then! That was Ballytruckle Road, yes? Think I have it at the right location, but the Flickr Map call that road Pearse Park...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] An Oldie, but a Goody! Now I'll always be giggling when people mention focus.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Excuse me but in defence of my 1906 sisters, their hairstyles were the height of fashion! And I bet you learned all those "womanly skills" like washing, sewing, ironing, cooking and cleaning in the army.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
When I was at school in the 1940s the girls did not have fancy hairstyles.
It was a sheet of newspaper and the nit comb for them.
I still think that these ladies are staff, not schoolgirls.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] I don't agree (sorry!). I've put a note on the 3 ladies who I think were staff, but I'm convinced that the others were pupils/students...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 58157940@N04
comment._content: Great photo of such pretty ladies, my Grandmother wore her hair like this & she looked so beautiful.....I like the white aprons, very nice....
